author: RNN Staff
title: Victim's father: Oregon shooter targeted Christians
text:
ROSEBURG, OR (RNN) - A shooting left multiple people dead Thursday at Umpqua Community College in Roseburg, OR, after a now-deceased shooter opened fire on campus.
The New York Times and several other news outlets have identified the shooter as Chris Haper Mercer, 26. Law enforcement officials have not released information on Mercer's motivation.
However, the father of a wounded student told CNN that the gunman targeted Christians, asking each of his victims if they were Christians.
During a press conference, Douglas County Sheriff John Hanlin said that gunfire exchanged between the first responding law enforcement officers and the shooter resulted in the suspect's death.
No officers were injured during the shooting. The sheriff said there were 10 casualties.
"I can tell you that this number is the best, most accurate information we have at the time," he said. "I've heard varying numbers and don't want to report a number that is inaccurate. Currently, we've got more to compound to do a thorough search, evaluate the scene or scenes, process many cars in the parking lot, and a ton of interviews to do."
Hanlin said the identities of victims would not be released for 24 to 48 hours. According to the Associated Press, four of the people injured during the deadly mass shooting remain hospitalized at Mercy Medical Center in Roseburg. They are expected to survive.
It reportedly began in the college's science building and moved to other classrooms. Responders said they found multiple victims in multiple rooms.
Umpqua student Larry Howell was on his way to class when he saw students running around him, he told NBC News .
"I turned around, I heard active shooter and I didn't need to be told twice," he said.
President Barack Obama addressed the nation after the shooting, taking time to emphatically call for tougher gun laws. This was the 15th time the president has addressed the nation after a massing shooting, according to CNN.
"It's not enough," he said. "It's not enough. We are the only advanced nation that sees these mass shootings every few months. Somehow, this has become routine. The reporting is routine. My response here at the podium is routine. The conversation and the aftermath - we've become numb to this."
The president chastised those who he said opposed "common sense gun legislation."
"And what has become routine, of course, is anyone who opposes common sense gun legislation," he said. "I can imagine the press releases that are being cranked out right now. This is something we should politicize. This is relative to our common life together."
LifeFlight deployed six medical helicopters to the scene, the company's CEO told reporters. Mercy Medical Center, a hospital near the site of the shooting, said an "unknown number" of wounded were coming in.
Police responded at 10:38 a.m. PT, according to the Douglas County Sheriff's Office.
Rep. Peter DeFazio, D-OR, said in a statement his thoughts and prayers were with the victims and their families, according to the Associated Press. He said once he found out more on what happened, he would work with Congress to find ways to prevent tragedies like this.
Roseburg, OR, an hour south of Eugene, has a population near 22,000 with logging as its primary industry. Umpqua Community College has 17 campus buildings on 100 acres with about 3,000 on-campus students. Nursing is the top major. The average age for students is 38, and 58 percent of students are female.
The college will be closed through the weekend. All activities are canceled until classes resume on Monday.
The area is a gun-free zone. Criminal charges would be greater should someone be caught carrying one.
The Oregon State Police have set up a family reunification, according to Superintendent Richard Evans of the Oregon State Police.
This shooting is the latest in a long line of school shootings. The most recent was in September, a history professor was killed by another faculty member during a shooting at Delta State University in Cleveland, MS.
Five people died during a school shooting in the cafeteria at Marysville-Pilchuch High School in Marysville, WA near Seattle in October 2014.
Thirty-two students and faculty were killed during the Virginia Tech shooting in 2007. It has been called the deadliest shooting rampage in U.S. history.
